Full Paragraph Text: We remain the only infant formula manufacturer included in FTSE’s responsible investment index, based on our performance in human rights, labour rights, responsible marketing of breast-milk substitutes and more.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a company's inclusion in an investment index based on performance metrics, but does not establish any explicit causal relationships between actors at different scales. It presents a static achievement rather than describing how one scale influences another.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The text describes one organization’s performance leading to its inclusion in an index run by another organization—both are Organizational. No explicit cross-scale causal link is stated.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The 'infant formula manufacturer' refers to a specific company.; Environmental and Societal: FTSE’s responsible investment index represents a market-level standard and evaluation system. gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] An infant formula manufacturer's performance directly causes its inclusion in a societal investment index.

This demonstrates a clear causal influence from the actions of a single organization to its status within a broader societal-level financial and ethical evaluation system. Only two distinct scales were necessary to capture this interaction.

Full Paragraph Text: We were ranked number one by the charity Oxfam in its 2014 scorecard, Behind the Brands. The survey scored 10 food and beverage companies on their efforts to improve food security.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a ranking outcome by Oxfam but does not establish any explicit causal relationships between actors at different scales. It only states that companies were scored on their efforts, without describing how those efforts causally influenced outcomes or how the ranking itself caused any changes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The text describes Oxfam ranking companies and mentions efforts to improve food security, but it does not state any explicit causal effects across different scales. No cross-scale causality is asserted.
o4_mini: Rationale: No explicit cross-scale causal links are present in the text.
gemini2.5: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Refers to Oxfam (a single NGO) and the 'We' company, as well as the 'efforts' originating from companies.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to the '10 food and beverage companies' as a collective body or sector being assessed by a scorecard like 'Behind the Brands', which typically compares and influences an industry segment, thus creating a 'system among organizations'.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'food security', a societal-level issue or system.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal] Oxfam's organizational scoring influences the food and beverage sector, while companies' efforts within that sector aim to improve food security.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes Oxfam (Organizational) scoring a group of food and beverage companies (interpreted as Inter-Organizational / Sector due to the context of a scorecard assessing an industry segment). It also explicitly states that these companies' efforts (Organizational) aim to improve food security (Environmental and Societal). Two distinct cross-scale causal links are identified: Oxfam's scoring action impacting the sector, and the companies' direct efforts impacting a societal issue. The phrase '10 food and beverage companies' is viewed as representing a sector being acted upon by the scorecard, rather than merely individual organizations.

Full Paragraph Text: The business environment was again marked by great uncertainty in 2014. Disruptive socio-economic and political change continued to affect growth in many parts of the world. In the emerging markets, economic volatility worsened as growth rates slowed and currencies weakened. In the developed markets, deflationary pressures and soft consumer demand resulted in a continued challenging trading environment. In the face of such uncertainty it was more important than ever to stay the course and remain loyal to our strategy, driving short-term performance while ensuring we made the right decisions to deliver our long-term goals. We took decisive steps to further our ambition to be the world’s recognised leading Nutrition, Health and Wellness company, trusted by all stakeholders, while again delivering financial results in 2014 that outperformed the market.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Socio-economic and political changes, market conditions, deflationary pressures, and consumer demand represent broad societal and economic systems; Organizational: The company ('we') taking decisive steps, staying loyal to strategy, and delivering financial results represents organizational-level actions and responses
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Market uncertainty and economic volatility prompted company to maintain strategic focus and take decisive action.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how broad environmental and societal factors (economic volatility, political changes, market conditions) directly influenced organizational responses (staying the course, taking decisive steps, strategic decisions). This represents a clear cross-scale causal relationship from societal-level conditions to organizational actions.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Macro conditions: uncertainty, socio-economic and political change, deflationary pressures, soft consumer demand.; Organizational: The company’s strategic response and actions to stay the course and deliver results.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal | Organizational] Macro uncertainty led the company to adhere to its strategy.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties macro uncertainty to the company’s strategic stance, creating a cross-scale causal link. Other statements describe macro-to-macro effects or performance outcomes without explicit cross-scale causality, so only this link is included.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph discusses various market conditions and company strategies but does not explicitly state any causal influences across different hierarchical scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: This scale includes macro-level factors such as 'business environment', 'socio-economic and political change', 'growth', 'economic volatility', 'currencies', 'deflationary pressures', 'soft consumer demand', 'challenging trading environment', 'uncertainty', and 'the market'.; Organizational: This scale refers to 'we' (the company), 'our strategy', 'our long-term goals', and 'financial results' as a single corporate entity.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Environmental and Societal uncertainty influenced the strategic decisions and priorities of the Organization.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states that the prevailing 'uncertainty' at the Environmental and Societal level directly influenced the strategic imperative for 'us' (the Organizational entity) to 'stay the course and remain loyal to our strategy'. Other observed interactions, such as socio-economic changes affecting growth, were within the same Environmental and Societal scale. The phrase 'outperformed the market' was interpreted as a comparative statement of performance rather than a direct causal influence on the market itself.

Full Paragraph Text: Through continuous innovation and renovation of our food and beverages portfolio we are able to offer people healthier and tastier choices at every stage of their life, at any time of the day. Science-based innovation enables us to enhance the quality of people’s diets, using our knowledge and our research and development capability to make a positive contribution to society. Wherever you are in the world, we have safe, nutritious products to help you care for yourself and your family. A few years ago, we expanded the boundaries of Nutrition, Health and Wellness with the creation of Nestlé Health Science, motivated by the opportunity to forge a major therapeutic role for nutrition in the management of health. In line with this broadened strategy, in 2014 the Board approved the sale of 48.5 million L’Oréal shares to L’Oréal for cancellation. Part of the proceeds were used for the acquisition of the 50% stake in our joint venture Galderma from L’Oréal, bringing our ownership of Galderma to 100%. Galderma formed the foundation of a new Nestlé subsidiary, Nestlé Skin Health. Its goal is to be recognised as the leading company in skin health, offering science-based solutions to protect, nourish and enhance skin, and where needed to treat, correct and restore damaged skin over the course of people’s lives. Nestlé Skin Health provides prescription drugs, self-medication, therapeutic skin care and aesthetic and corrective medicine, allowing us to compete in the growing and promising multi-billion global skincare market. Nestlé Skin Health was further strengthened by the acquisition of the full rights to commercialise several key aesthetic dermatology products in the United States and Canada.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: People, families, and individuals who consume products and receive health benefits from Nestlé's offerings; Organizational: Nestlé as a company developing products, making strategic decisions, and creating subsidiaries like Nestlé Health Science and Nestlé Skin Health
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Nestlé's innovation and product development enhances people's diets and provides health solutions to individuals and families.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how Nestlé (Organizational) develops and offers products that directly benefit people's health and nutrition (Individual). The company's strategic decisions, R&D capabilities, and product portfolio creation causally influence individual health outcomes and dietary quality.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé and its units (Nestlé Health Science, Nestlé Skin Health) take actions (innovation, product provision).; Individual: People/consumers/families whose diets and self-care are affected by the products and innovations.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Nestlé’s innovation and products causally improve people’s diet quality and ability to care for themselves.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states organizational actions improve individuals’ diets and self-care. Other potential links (to society or markets) were excluded to keep within the scale limit and avoid weaker inferences.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: The text discusses how products benefit people and families, indicating a focus on individual health.; Organizational: Nestlé and its subsidiaries are mentioned as organizations driving innovation and product offerings.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Nestlé's innovations in health and wellness directly benefit individuals by providing healthier choices and skin health solutions.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links demonstrate how Nestlé's organizational actions, such as product innovation and acquisitions, lead to improved health outcomes for individuals. The focus remains on these two scales, as they clearly illustrate the causal relationships present in the text.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'people', 'people’s diets', 'yourself and your family', and 'people’s lives' as direct recipients or beneficiaries of products/services.; Organizational: Refers to 'we' (Nestlé), 'our food and beverages portfolio', 'Nestlé Health Science', 'Nestlé Skin Health', and 'the Board' as specific companies or internal units.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'society' and the 'global skincare market' as broader systems or societal contexts impacted by organizational actions.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] An organizational entity innovates and offers products, causally influencing individuals' health and diets, and contributing to broader society and markets.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph focuses on Nestlé (Organizational) as the central actor, whose innovations and products directly influence individuals' health and choices. Its actions are also explicitly aimed at contributing to society and competing within the global market (Environmental and Societal). While an explicit Inter-Organizational link was present ('joint venture Galderma formed the foundation of Nestlé Skin Health'), it was excluded to adhere to the protocol's limit of three distinct scales across all links, prioritizing the continuous and overarching interactions with individuals and societal systems.

Full Paragraph Text: These developments ensure that, building on the strong foundations of our food and beverages business and guided increasingly by science, we can further expand our portfolio to provide promising platforms for future growth in line with our strategy of Nutrition, Health and Wellness. At the same time, we continue the drive to ensure our company is organised efficiently and effectively to deliver continuous profitable growth over the long term. With this objective in mind we made some key decisions, adapting our organisational structure to better prepare ourselves today to meet the challenges of tomorrow.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes internal organizational strategy and restructuring decisions but does not explicitly state any causal influences between different scales. All actions mentioned (expanding portfolio, organizing efficiently, making key decisions, adapting structure) are internal organizational activities without clear cross-scale causality to or from other scales like individuals, inter-organizational systems, or environmental/societal factors.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: “Science” is presented as a guiding societal-level knowledge system.; Organizational: “Our company” and its portfolio/organizational structure are firm-level actors/actions.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Science guides the company’s portfolio expansion and growth approach.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly says the company is “guided increasingly by science,” which causally shapes its portfolio expansion. Other statements describe internal reorganization effects within the firm, not cross-scale links.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company is adapting its structure to improve efficiency and growth.; Societal: The strategy of Nutrition, Health and Wellness aligns with broader societal health goals.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Societal] The company's organizational changes aim to align with societal health and wellness goals.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the company's organizational adaptations are explicitly tied to its strategy that addresses societal health needs. No other distinct scales were present.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] The company's organizational development is influenced by guiding science and the challenges of the external environment, driving its portfolio expansion and structural adaptation.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph identifies two explicit cross-scale links where Environmental and Societal factors influence the Organizational level. First, 'science' (Environmental and Societal) guides the company's (Organizational) portfolio expansion. Second, the company's 'organisational structure' (Organizational) is adapted in response to 'challenges of tomorrow' (Environmental and Societal), highlighting an external driver for internal change.

Full Paragraph Text: While our company continues to benefit from its decentralised structure, allowing key decisions to be made as close as possible to consumers, there is still an important opportunity to better leverage our scale. That is why in 2014 we set up Nestlé Business Excellence at Executive Board Level, combining GLOBE (Nestlé’s Global Business Excellence function) with Nestlé Business Services (our shared operation for transactional services around the world) and Nestlé Con tinuous Excellence (our continuous improvement and LEAN programme). Through a focus on three areas: Simplifying, Standardising and Sharing, Nestlé Business Excellence will allow us to decrease structural costs and operational expenses, freeing up resources to support growth. This will also allow our markets to keep a sharp focus on generating demand.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé as a single company making structural decisions and creating new business units; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Multiple markets and decentralized operations that span different organizational units working together
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Nestlé's Business Excellence initiative enables markets to focus on demand generation.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how Nestlé as a single organization created a new business structure that explicitly allows multiple markets (inter-organizational entities) to operate more effectively. The causality is clear: organizational restructuring enables improved market operations.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: All described effects occur within one organization and its internal units. No explicit causal influence is stated between actors at different scales (e.g., Individual, Inter-Org, or Societal).

o4_mini: Rationale: The links illustrate how the company's internal structure (Organizational) influences its collaborative functions (Inter-Organizational), which in turn affect market dynamics (Environmental and Societal). The focus on demand generation connects these scales explicitly.

All identified causal links operate solely within the Organizational scale.

Full Paragraph Text: We have integrated the Maghreb, the Middle East, the North East Africa region, Turkey and Israel into Zone Europe to form Zone EMENA (Europe, Middle East and North Africa). This balances the different consumer dynamics and opportunities in each geography. Additionally it allows a sharper focus in Zone Asia, Oceania and Africa, a fast-growing part

It only explains the rationale for the restructuring (balancing consumer dynamics, allowing sharper focus) without describing how actors at one scale influence actors at another scale.

Full Paragraph Text: The new Nestlé Business Excellence function is led by Chris Johnson, the former head of Zone Americas. Zone Americas is now led by Laurent Freixe, the former head of Zone Europe, and the new Zone EMENA by Luis Cantarell, who previously was in charge of Nestlé Nutrition and Nestlé Health Science. The new head of Nestlé Nutrition is Heiko Schipper, who was formerly responsible for our Global Infant Nutrition division. Nestlé Health Science is led by Greg Behar, who joined the company from Boehringer Ingelheim in July. The newly established Nestlé Skin Health is led by Humberto Antunes, former ly the Chief Executive Officer of our joint venture Galderma.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph describes organizational restructuring and leadership appointments within Nestlé. All actors mentioned are individuals (executives) and all actions involve role assignments within the same organizational entity (Nestlé and its divisions). There are no cross-scale causal interactions described - only internal personnel changes at the organizational level.

Full Paragraph Text: We further reinforced our business through continued active portfolio management, reviewing the performance of different products in different markets to assess strate gic fit, the extent to which they were accretive against our financial targets, and what investments were necessary to deliver growth. We made choices about where we wanted to invest, where we wanted to improve, and what we wanted to divest. Making such choices enables us to align our resourc es behind our best ideas, products and categories, to deliver sustained financial performance and help us on our journey to recognised Nutrition, Health and Wellness leadership over the short term and the long term.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes internal organizational activities (portfolio management, performance review, investment decisions) without any explicit causal interactions between different scales. All actions are taken by the organization itself regarding its own products, markets, and resources. No cross-scale causality is demonstrated.

Full Paragraph Text: We also announced new investments and research collaborations, which will enhance our ability to deliver sci ence-based solutions to improve the quality of people’s lives. A newly-announced research partnership with the EpiGen consortium will help us to better develop our understanding of the influence of nutrition and genetics at the beginning of life and continue to build our knowledge in this important area. The Nestlé Institute of Health Sciences began a collab oration on a groundbreaking project, which could one day lead to the development of made-to-measure vitamin com binations tailored to individual needs. Our company was founded almost 150 years ago on the product Henri Nestlé invented, farine lactée. It saved the life of a child. Today we continue to invest in science-based innovation to ensure we can answer current and future needs.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé as a company making investments, forming research partnerships, and developing products through its Institute of Health Sciences; Individual: People whose lives are improved by the science-based solutions, and individuals who would receive tailored vitamin combinations
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Nestlé's research investments and collaborations deliver science-based solutions to improve individual lives.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how Nestlé (organizational scale) through its research partnerships and investments causally influences individuals by developing solutions to improve their quality of life and creating personalized vitamin combinations. This represents a direct cross-scale interaction from organizational actions to individual outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: Research partnership with the EpiGen consortium; Organizational: Nestlé / Nestlé Institute of Health Sciences increasing capability and understanding; Individual: People’s lives and a child beneficiary of a product

gpt5: Rationale: Text states the EpiGen partnership helps the company develop understanding (cross-scale: inter-org to org). It also states company efforts and a product improve/save lives (org to individual). Speculative claims were excluded.

o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the organizational efforts of Nestlé directly aim to enhance the quality of life for individuals, establishing a clear causal influence from the organizational scale to the individual scale.

These actions are directly stated to impact Individual well-being and needs. The identified three scales are clearly defined and demonstrate explicit causal influences, with multiple links highlighting the Organizational impact on Individual lives.

Full Paragraph Text: It is our fundamental belief that to be successful over time we need to create value for our shareholders while at the same time creating value for society. We call this Creating Shared Value. To prosper we have to take a long-term view, framed in a robust set of principles and values that are based on respect: respect for people, respect for the environment, and respect for the world we live in. What we do and the effects of what we do are highly visible. It is our responsibility to connect with different stakeholders, to show transparency and build trust. We have therefore again in 2014 reported on our social performance and our compliance in our Nestlé in society report, and our progress towards meeting the tough targets we set ourselves.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph presents Nestlé's philosophy and general approach to stakeholder engagement but contains no explicit causal relationships between different scales. The text describes beliefs, principles, and reporting activities without specifying concrete actions that causally influence actors at different hierarchical levels.
gpt5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: “We”/Nestlé is one company taking actions (reporting, creating value).; Environmental and Societal: “Society,” “stakeholders,” and public trust/transparency are societal-level outcomes.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The company’s reporting and value creation aim to increase transparency, trust, and value for society.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties Nestlé’s actions to societal outcomes (value creation, transparency/trust among stakeholders). Only Organizational and Environmental/Societal scales are involved, satisfying cross-scale causality.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé is an organization that creates value for shareholders.; Societal: The text discusses creating value for society, indicating a societal-level impact.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Societal] Nestlé aims to create value for both shareholders and society, indicating a cross-scale interaction.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the text explicitly states that the organization's success is tied to creating societal value, demonstrating a causal influence from the organizational scale to the societal scale.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to specific people or informal groups like 'shareholders'.; Organizational: Refers to 'we' (the company, Nestlé) and its internal actions and reports.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to broad societal-level systems such as 'society', 'the environment', 'the world we live in', and 'different stakeholders' when treated as a collective societal entity.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The company (Organizational) creates value for shareholders (Individual) and society (Environmental and Societal), and builds trust with stakeholders (Environmental and Societal).
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how the company (Organizational) causes influence by creating value for individuals (shareholders) and for society (Environmental and Societal systems). Additionally, the company's responsibility 'to show transparency and build trust' with 'different stakeholders' is interpreted as an interaction between the Organizational scale and the Environmental and Societal scale, covering broader societal groups and their perceptions. These three distinct scales (Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal) cover all explicit cross-scale interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we held another successful Creating Shared Value forum, this time at the Nestlé Research Center in Lausanne, co-organised for the first time with a United Nations body, the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). The President of the Swiss Confederation used his address to the event to plead for water to become a self-standing goal of the future global development agenda. At the event we renewed our long-standing partnership with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies. Since 2006 this collaboration has focused on the improvement of rural communities’ access to clean water and sanitation.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé as a single company hosting the forum and partnering with other organizations like the International Federation of Red Cross; Environmental and Societal: Rural communities receiving improved access to clean water and sanitation through the collaboration

Full Paragraph Text: Currently, at the United Nations there are intense discussions about the global development goals for the period after 2015. At the same time, governments and international organ isations are increasingly reliant on the expertise, experience and resources of the private sector to help address some of the world’s most pressing problems. This offers an opportunity for global companies such as Nestlé to make a valu able contribution, in partnership with governments and civil society. We are participating actively in the policy dialogue in areas which will deeply influence our future business, such as food security, nutrition and health, water, sustainability, and human rights.

Full Paragraph Text: Our success has always been based upon our determination to stay the course and look ahead, to understand the environment in which we operate, to organise ourselves to seize opportunities to deliver profitable growth, now and in the future. Although we are operating in a challenging and turbulent economic environment, we see these as fascinating times, full of opportunities. We continue to commit ourselves to ambitious financial targets. We aim to achieve organic growth of around 5% to 6%, improvements in margins and underlying earnings per share in constant currencies, as well as capital efficiency. There will be years when we exceed our ambition and years where we come close, but this is the line we want to walk over time.

While it mentions 'the environment in which we operate' and 'challenging economic environment,' these are contextual references without explicit causal relationships between different scales. No specific actors at different scales are described as influencing each other causally.

Full Paragraph Text: Start Healthy Stay Healthy is our interactive, science-based education programme designed to help parents and care givers provide nutritionally and developmentally adequate nutrition in the crucial first 1000 days of life. We help to guide parents and caregivers to raise healthier children and help healthcare professionals have a greater impact on the nutritional aspects of care of future generations.

Full Paragraph Text: We continue to reinforce our leadership in the area of chil dren’s nutrition. By the end of 2014 98% of all our products for children met the Nestlé Nutritional Foundation criteria for children. These criteria are based on nutrition science and public health dietary recommendations from bodies such as the World Health Organization and the Institute of Medicine. Our products are evaluated against these criteria using the Nestlé Nutritional Profiling System which determines their nutritional value and whether they achieve Nestlé Nutritional Foundation status.

Full Paragraph Text: We are carrying out large-scale studies together with lead ing scientists of children’s diet and lifestyles, based on the success of the Nestlé Feeding Infants and Toddlers Study. In addition to dietary intakes and behaviours, our research explores family dynamics around diets and key lifestyle patterns of children while documenting their height and weight. We use this data to support our product reformulation, consumer communication and educational programmes, and we share the results with the wider scientific community, non-governmental organisations and others.

This represents explicit cross-scale causality from Individual to Organizational scale.

Full Paragraph Text: We ensure global compliance with responsible advertising and marketing standards for children, abiding by external pledges such as the EU Pledge. At the end of 2014, the Ex ecutive Board approved an updated and strengthened Nestlé Marketing Communication to Children Policy, which will come into effect in December 2015. To ensure consistent and effective implementation, detailed internal guidelines have been developed and external stakeholders are encouraged to provide feedback via our Tell us reporting mechanism. We have phased out our marketing communication in schools and reinforced our health and wellness education activities, particularly those that positively impact children’s development and support governments’ goals to increase physical activity.
claude4: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé as a company implementing policies, developing guidelines, and conducting marketing activities; Environmental and Societal: External pledges like EU Pledge, governments setting goals for physical activity, and external stakeholders providing feedback
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] External pledges drive Nestlé's compliance policies while company activities support government goals.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph shows bidirectional causality between Nestlé (Organizational) and external regulatory/governmental systems (Environmental and Societal). External pledges explicitly drive compliance behavior, while company activities explicitly support government objectives.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: External pledges such as the EU Pledge are multi-organization commitments influencing members.; Organizational: Nestlé (and its Executive Board/policies) acts as a single organization.; Individual: Children whose development is impacted by the company’s education activities.
gpt5: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational, Individual] External pledges shape Nestlé’s policies, which in turn improve children’s development.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties external pledges to company behavior and states company activities positively impact children. A potential Organizational -> Environmental and Societal link (supporting governments’ goals) was omitted to keep within the three-scale limit.

o4_mini: Rationale: The links demonstrate how Nestlé's organizational policies are influenced by societal goals and, conversely, how these policies aim to impact societal outcomes. Both scales are essential for understanding the interactions.

gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how Nestlé (Organizational) adheres to societal standards (Environmental and Societal) and receives feedback from external stakeholders (Environmental and Societal). It then describes how Nestlé's activities (Organizational) directly benefit individuals (children's development) and support broader governmental objectives (Environmental and Societal), showcasing clear two-way cross-scale interactions. All identified links involve Individual, Organizational, and Environmental and Societal scales, adhering to the three-scale limit.

Full Paragraph Text: By the end of 2014 the Nestlé Healthy Kids programme was in 73 countries, supporting initiatives which demonstrate how appropriate nutrition and exercise can improve the health of children and their communities. In addition, our own studies in four countries have shown that two thirds of children are insufficiently hydrated when they arrive at school. In 2014 we provided tools and information that schools, parents and caregivers need to ensure children learn about the benefits of healthy hydration.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé as a company implementing the Healthy Kids programme and conducting studies; Individual: Children, parents, caregivers, and schools as specific people and informal groups receiving tools and information

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes Nestlé (organizational scale) explicitly providing tools and information that causally enables schools, parents and caregivers (individual scale) to educate children about healthy hydration. This represents a clear cross-scale causal influence from organization to individuals.

gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Nestlé provided tools/info needed by parents/caregivers and schools, enabling action. It also states schools ensure children learn, indicating organizational-to-individual influence. Other claims lack clear actors.

These are single organizations or their specific programs/units.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to broader societal structures like 'communities'.

Another clear link is from Organizational (schools) to Individual (children). The three scales (Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal) cover all explicitly mentioned actors with cross-scale interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: United for Healthier Kids is a platform, created by Nestlé in 2014, where society can engage and collaborate to find ways to improve the health and wellness of children, from conception to the age of 12 years. In Mexico, a TV series was launched which supports and encourages five families looking to change their eating and lifestyle habits over six months. The platform has also been launched in the Philippines.

claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Nestlé's platform supports families in changing their eating habits.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear causal relationship where Nestlé (organizational scale) created a platform that directly supports and encourages specific families (individual scale) to change their behaviors. This represents explicit cross-scale influence from company to households.

Full Paragraph Text: Through innovation and renovation we continue to make our products tastier and healthier. In line with the recommendations from public health authorities, we are reducing the amount of salt, sugar and saturated fats in our products as part of our contribution towards the fight against non-communicable diseases in society. Our reduction targets are in cluded in our public nutrition commitments (detailed in the Nestlé in society report) so our progress can be measured. We are also ensuring that whole grains are the primary ingredient in our breakfast cereals for children and teenagers.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Public health authorities represent societal-level institutions that provide recommendations and guidance; Organizational: The company (Nestlé) is making specific product changes and commitments in response to these recommendations
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Public health recommendations drive company to reformulate products with less salt, sugar and fats.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly shows public health authorities (societal-level actors) influencing organizational behavior through recommendations that the company explicitly follows in reformulating their products.

gpt5: Rationale: Public health authorities (societal) explicitly prompt the company (organizational) to reduce salt, sugar, and fats. The company states these reductions contribute to society’s fight against NCDs. Other elements are intra-organizational or not cross-scale.

Full Paragraph Text: We want to help people who buy our products to make informed decisions by giving them better nutritional information on our product labels. We are enhancing our portion guidance and have committed to print GDAs (Guideline Daily Amounts) on the front of all relevant packaging. These make it easier for people to see how much salt, sugar or fat is in the product, and how the amounts compare to reference daily guidelines. Nestlé Portion Guidance is a voluntary initiative

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear causal relationship where Nestlé (organizational scale) implements labeling changes that directly influence individual consumers' ability to make informed decisions. The company's voluntary initiative of printing nutritional information is explicitly designed to affect individual behavior.

Full Paragraph Text: In parts of the world where people find it difficult to get essential vitamins and minerals in their daily diets, we fortify foods to help them and their families stay healthy. We are on track to deliver our commitment of 200 billion servings of micronutrient fortified foods and beverages annually around the world by next year. In 2014 we continued to extend the reach of our microfortification programmes, focusing on categories for children and women of child-bearing age, such as fortified infant cereals and growing-up milks.

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear causal relationship where an organizational actor (the company) takes specific actions (fortifying foods, extending microfortification programmes) that directly benefit individual actors (people, families, children, women). The company explicitly states they fortify foods 'to help them and their families stay healthy,' establishing clear cross-scale causality from organizational policy to individual health outcomes.

Full Paragraph Text: The importance of the right nutrition and feeding practices during the first 1000 days of life, from conception to a child’s second birthday, is now widely accepted by the public health community. Full Paragraph Text: It is our fundamental belief that for a company to prosper over the long term we need to create value for shareholders while at the same time creating value for society. We call this Creating Shared Value.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph presents a philosophical statement about Creating Shared Value but contains no explicit causal relationships between actors at different scales. It describes a belief or principle rather than specific actions or influences between identifiable entities.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: A company is a single organization acting.; Environmental and Societal: Society refers to societal-level stakeholders and systems.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The company’s actions are stated to create value for society.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states the organization creates value for society, a cross-scale causal effect. A parallel link to shareholders (Individual) is implied but omitted to keep the scale count minimal.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph discusses the need for a company to create value for shareholders and society but does not explicitly state a causal influence between different scales.

gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes how an Organizational actor (company) creates value for Individual actors (shareholders) and Environmental and Societal actors (society). Crucially, the text explicitly states that the company's own prosperity (Organizational scale) is conditional upon creating this value for both shareholders and society, establishing reciprocal cross-scale influences. All three identified scales are explicitly involved in these causal statements, meeting the scale limitation.

Full Paragraph Text: In the Nestlé in society report we detail our progress towards meeting our 38 Creating Shared Value commitments (including three new ones for 2014). These commitments, which we introduced in 2013, make it possible for stakeholders to hold us accountable, while at the same time encouraging our management, and all our employees, to achieve continuous improvement. Creating Shared Value requires compliance with the highest standards of business practice, including international codes and standards as well as our own.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé as a company making commitments and having management structures; Individual: All employees who are encouraged to achieve continuous improvement
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Nestlé's commitments encourage all employees to achieve continuous improvement.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how Nestlé's organizational commitments explicitly encourage individual employees toward continuous improvement. While stakeholders are mentioned, their role is described as holding the company accountable rather than being influenced by or influencing across scales in a causal manner.

gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Nestlé’s commitments spur employees to improve.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states that organizational commitments encourage individuals (management and employees). A second valid effect on 'stakeholders' exists but was omitted to avoid duplicate Organizational -> Individual paths.

Conversely, the organization's core initiative (Organizational) is explicitly stated to require compliance with broader international standards (Environmental and Societal). All three identified scales are clearly defined and directly involved in explicit causal relationships.

Full Paragraph Text: At our 2014 CSV Forum, we announced that we will transform our European Youth Employment Initiative into a global programme. The initiative has two aims – to recruit and develop the next generation of Nestlé leaders and to help young people with the transition from education to work.

Only two distinct scales were identified as having explicit cross-scale interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: For the Nestlé Needs YOUth programme in Europe, where one in four people under the age of 25 is unemployed, we pledged to offer 20000 jobs, apprenticeships and traineeships over three years, and establish readiness for work activities across our operations. We are well on schedule to achieve this with 11832 job and training opportunities created by the end of 2014 and around 1600 readiness for work events completed.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé as a company implementing the Needs YOUth programme with specific pledges and operations; Individual: Young people under 25 who are unemployed and receiving jobs, apprenticeships, traineeships, and readiness activities

These three scales cover all explicit cross-scale interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: We built on the success of this initiative in 2014 by establishing the Alliance for YOUth, a collaboration with around 200 other companies, to scale up and coordinate our efforts to tackle youth unemployment. The efforts of the Alliance for YOUth will result in the creation of more than 100000 opportunities for young people in Europe.

Full Paragraph Text: By 2020, one billion people in the world will be over 60, in creasing the burden on society from obesity and chronic diseases. It is estimated global healthcare costs could rise to between USD 5–10 trillion by the end of the decade. At the same time scientific understanding of health, disease and the potential of nutrition is growing.

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly establishes causality where individual health conditions (aging population with obesity and chronic diseases) directly cause societal-level impacts (increased burden on society and rising global healthcare costs). The scientific understanding mentioned is descriptive context without clear causal links to other scales.

Full Paragraph Text: Nestlé Health Science aims to champion the role of nutritional therapies that have proven clinical and health economic value, and improve the quality of people’s lives. The company focuses on three areas: Consumer Care, which aims to address specific health conditions with an emphasis on enhancing ‘healthy ageing’; Medical Nutrition, which supplies hospitals and other healthcare facilities; and Novel Therapeutic nutrition, which works on new nutritional therapies (including pre scribed medicines) for specific diseases and conditions that would be administered by a health professional.

It presents static descriptions of what the company 'aims to do' and 'focuses on' without describing actual actions that influence or are influenced by actors at other scales.

The brand raises awareness of heart health with in-store health checks and offers toll-free phone contact with doctors to discuss cardiovascular health.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014, we transformed a dairy factory in Mexico into the company’s first ‘zero water’ manufacturing site in the world. Cow’s milk is 88% water, so by extracting some of it to use in the factory’s systems, we are saving enough water to meet the average daily consumption of 6400 people in the surrounding area.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company that transformed the dairy factory and implemented the zero water manufacturing system; Environmental and Societal: The surrounding area community of 6400 people whose daily water consumption needs are being met through the water savings
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Company's zero water factory saves water equivalent to daily needs of 6400 local residents.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear causal relationship where an organizational action (transforming the factory) directly benefits the broader community by conserving water resources. Only two scales are involved, making this a straightforward cross-scale interaction.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company transformed a dairy factory into a 'zero water' site and changed factory systems.; Individual: People in the surrounding area whose average daily water consumption could be met.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] A zero-water factory saves water sufficient to meet the daily needs of 6400 nearby people.
gpt5: Rationale: The company’s change to a zero-water manufacturing process explicitly causes water savings benefiting individuals. No other cross-scale causal effects are stated.

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The dairy factory's water-saving efforts impact the water consumption of the local community.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the factory's initiative to save water has a direct positive effect on the water availability for the surrounding area's population, demonstrating a clear cross-scale interaction.

gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states that the company's (Organizational scale) action of saving water directly influences the water consumption of people (Individual scale). No other cross-scale interactions are mentioned, as the transformation of the factory and water extraction processes are internal to the Organizational scale, and their impact on individuals is the only explicit cross-scale effect.

Full Paragraph Text: The new technology used at the factory in Jalisco, Mexico, heats milk at low pressure to remove some of the water. The resulting steam is then condensed and treated and used to clean machines. It is then recycled and used again. The process reduces by 15% the total amount of water used by Nestlé Mexico. Work is now underway to deploy similar tech nology in five other manufacturing sites in water stressed are as around the world. It is just one of a number of water-saving initiatives we have introduced in recent years, allowing us to reduce total water withdrawal in absolute terms by almost one third in the last decade.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé Mexico as a specific company implementing water-saving technology and initiatives; Environmental and Societal: Water-stressed areas around the world representing broader environmental conditions that influence corporate deployment decisions
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Water-stressed conditions drive Nestlé to deploy water-saving technology across multiple sites.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph shows clear causality where environmental conditions (water stress in various global areas) explicitly influence organizational decisions (Nestlé's technology deployment strategy). The company's response to environmental pressures represents a direct cross-scale interaction.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: All described causes and effects occur within one organization (factory/Nestlé Mexico). No explicit causal impact on societal/environmental systems is stated; 'water-stressed areas' is context, not an effect.

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Nestlé Mexico's water-saving technology influences broader sectoral initiatives across multiple sites.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as Nestlé Mexico's implementation of technology directly influences the deployment of similar initiatives in other manufacturing sites, showcasing a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: 'Nestlé Mexico', 'factory in Jalisco, Mexico', 'other manufacturing sites', and 'we' (referring to Nestlé) are all specific corporate entities or locations operating as single organizations.; Environmental and Societal: 'water stressed areas around the world' refers to a broad environmental and societal condition, not a specific organization.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Water stressed areas around the world influence Nestlé's deployment strategy for water-saving technology at its manufacturing sites.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph establishes a clear cross-scale link where the societal condition of 'water stressed areas' (Environmental and Societal) explicitly dictates the locations where Nestlé (Organizational) is undertaking 'work... to deploy similar technology'. This demonstrates a causal influence from the broader environmental context on the organization's strategic actions.

Full Paragraph Text: Today our people are carrying out 170 water-saving projects in Nestlé factories, which will save around 3.6 million cubic metres of water.

Full Paragraph Text: In March 2014, we opened the Nestlé Food Safety Institute in Beijing, China. The new centre has three objectives: to collaborate with Chinese universities, research institutes and regulatory authorities in food safety research; to increase our ability to assess risks, anticipate problems and provide accurate information in any food safety situations; and to engage on scientific communication and food safety training.

This represents a clear cross-scale interaction from organizational to inter-organizational level through explicit collaboration.

Full Paragraph Text: Nestlé is deeply integrated into people’s lives with many buying our products on a daily basis. This gives us opportunities to contribute meaningfully to their quality of life. It is what our promise of Good Food, Good Life is all about: offering the best tasting, healthiest choices across a wide range of food and beverages, from morning to night and throughout life, helping people to live more enjoyable, healthy lives.

Full Paragraph Text: However, today, even brands that enjoy a high level of loyalty and trust need attention grabbing, engaging consumer communication to ensure they remain relevant to consumers. Therefore, excellence in brand building discipline and conviction about the importance of strong, sustainable brand equity is more important than ever, especially in an increasingly complex and crowded digital world.

Full Paragraph Text: The successful roll-out of Maggi Oats Noodles demonstrated that healthy eating can be both enjoyable and tasty. Strong sales of the new product show that it is also good business. Maggi Oats Noodles meet Nestlé Nutritional Foundation criteria, which are based on public health recommendations. The consumer communication reinforces the importance for families to start the day with a well-balanced breakfast, including fruits and milk. In 2014, we continued to renovate Maggi products all around the world, reducing salt and fat and improving their nutritional benefits.

Full Paragraph Text: The Maggi company began selling powdered soups in Switzerland in 1885. Julius Maggi had pioneered the production of pea and bean soups at the request of the Swiss Public Welfare Society to address the dietary deficiency of the work ing population. The advent of factory work for women meant less time to prepare food, and the soups were a convenient and nourishing alternative.
claude4: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Swiss Public Welfare Society represents a societal-level organization addressing population-wide issues; Organizational: Maggi company as a specific business entity developing and selling products; Individual: Working women and the working population as specific people affected by factory work conditions
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] Society requests company to develop products addressing workers' dietary needs.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear chain where a societal organization requests corporate action, which then serves individual workers. Two separate cross-scale links capture this: society influencing company, and company serving individuals.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Societal shift: the advent of factory work for women.; Individual: Women/working individuals having less time to prepare food.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Individual] Factory work’s rise reduced women’s time to cook.
gpt5: Rationale: Explicit causality links a societal labor shift to reduced individual cooking time. Other plausible org-to-individual influences are present but would add a third scale, so the clearest cross-scale link was prioritized.
o4_mini: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to the working population who benefited from the soups.; Organizational: Refers to the Maggi company as a specific organization.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to the Swiss Public Welfare Society addressing societal dietary deficiencies.

o4_mini: Rationale: The links show a clear causal influence from the societal level (Public Welfare Society) to the organizational level (Maggi company), and then from the organizational level to the individual level (working population). Only three scales were involved, making the links straightforward.

gemini2.5: Final Link: Environmental and Societal -> Individual (Swiss Public Welfare Society requested Julius Maggi)
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Julius Maggi (a specific person), women, and the working population (specific people/informal groups).; Organizational: The Maggi company (a single company).; Environmental and Societal: The Swiss Public Welfare Society (a societal-level institution), and factory work (a societal-level system/condition).

The Swiss Public Welfare Society (E&S) directly influenced Julius Maggi (Individual), who then influenced the Maggi company (Organizational). Separately, societal changes like factory work (E&S) impacted women (Individual).

Full Paragraph Text: Parents want their children to make the most of their potential. Nestlé Milo, which is mainly consumed by children aged 7–12, can help to provide the nourishing energy they need to succeed. Activ-Go plays a role in energy release, muscle function, bone maintenance and red blood cell formation, all essential for physical activity.

While parents (Individual) and Nestlé (Organizational) are mentioned, there is no clear statement that parents' wants cause Nestlé to act, or that Nestlé's product directly influences parental behavior - only descriptive statements about what parents want and what the product can do.

Full Paragraph Text: Nestlé Milo celebrated its 80th birthday in 2014. It was created by Nestlé engineer Thomas Mayne to help children who had poor diets get sufficient nutrition. He created Nestlé Milo from malt, milk and cocoa to give children the nutritious energy they need to get the best out of their day. It was launched at the Sydney Easter Show in 1934.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph provides historical information about Nestlé Milo's creation and launch but does not describe any causal interactions between different scales. While it mentions an individual engineer (Thomas Mayne) and an organization (Nestlé), there is no explicit causality described between these scales - only factual background about product development and launch details.

gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links an individual’s action to the creation of a brand/product and the product’s effect on children. Only Individual and Organizational scales are involved; other entities lack explicit cross-scale causality.
o4_mini: Rationale: No explicit cross-scale causal interactions are present in the text.

gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links an individual (Thomas Mayne) to the creation of an organizational product (Nestlé Milo), establishing an Individual -> Organizational link. It also states the product's purpose was to benefit individuals (children), creating an Organizational -> Individual link. Only two distinct scales were necessary to capture these explicit interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 Nestlé’s organic growth was 4.5%, composed of 2.3% real internal growth and 2.2% pricing. Sales were CHF 91.6 billion, down 0.6%, impacted by negative foreign exchange of –5.5%. Acquisitions, net of divestitures, added 0.4% to sales.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph presents only financial performance metrics and statistics for Nestlé without describing any actors taking actions that causally influence other actors across different scales. The text focuses on numerical data about growth rates, sales figures, and foreign exchange impacts rather than causal relationships between entities at different hierarchical levels.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Nestlé's sales and growth figures refer to one company.; Environmental and Societal: Negative foreign exchange reflects macroeconomic/capital market conditions.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Negative foreign exchange conditions reduced Nestlé’s reported sales.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links macro foreign exchange movements to Nestlé’s sales impact, a cross-scale causal effect. Other elements (pricing, internal growth, acquisitions) are intra-organizational and thus excluded.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph discusses financial metrics and growth percentages without indicating any causal influence between different hierarchical scales.

Only these three distinct scales show explicit causal interactions in the text.

Full Paragraph Text: The Group’s trading operating profit was CHF 14.0 billion, representing a margin of 15.3%, up 10 basis points, and up 30 basis points in constant currencies. The cost of goods sold fell by 30 basis points as a percentage of sales, driven by product mix and pricing actions and savings created by Nestlé Continuous Excellence which more than offset increases in raw material costs. Distribution costs were up by 10 basis points. Total marketing and administration expenses rose by 10 basis points as we increased consumer facing marketing support for our brands.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph presents financial performance metrics and cost structure analysis without identifying specific actors or explicit causal relationships between different organizational scales. The text describes outcomes (profit margins, cost changes) but does not specify which actors at different scales caused these changes or were affected by them.

gpt5: Rationale: Explicit wording links societal-level raw material cost increases to the organization's cost of goods sold. Other drivers (product mix, pricing, internal program) are intra-organizational and thus excluded to maintain cross-scale focus.

While 'raw material costs' could potentially relate to Inter-Organizational or Environmental/Societal scales, the text only states 'increases in raw material costs' as a given factor, not attributing its cause to any specific external actor or scale. Full Paragraph Text: The Zone’s organic growth was supported by double-digit growth for Nescafé Dolce Gusto and strong performances in ambient dairy and petcare. In North America growth improved towards the end of the year while in Latin America good growth was helped by pricing, reflecting inflationary pressures.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes business performance metrics and growth patterns across product categories and geographic regions, but does not identify specific actors taking actions that causally influence actors at different scales. Terms like 'The Zone's organic growth' and 'inflationary pressures' describe outcomes or conditions rather than explicit causal relationships between identifiable actors at different hierarchical levels.

Only two scales were involved, fitting the constraint.

Full Paragraph Text: Our performance in North America was affected by the frozen category. Projects are underway to reposition Lean Cuisine, Hot Pockets and Stouffers. They address all elements of the marketing mix, reflecting trends such as organic and ethnic, enhancing the brands’ relevance to consumers. We are taking the same approach in frozen pizza where our California Pizza Kitchen did well. In ice cream the super premium segment performed well with Gelato, and snacks returned to growth, although the premium segment was subdued. In confectionery the successful roll-out of Butterfinger Peanut Butter Cups continued. Innovations like Natural Bliss and seasonal renovations of flavours helped Coffee-mate de liver good growth. Innovation also ensured the petcare busi ness in North America continued to grow with Dog Chow, Pro Plan and Tidy Cats Lightweight cat litter as highlights. The launch of Beyond natural pet food gained momentum.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company is repositioning brands, launching products, and implementing marketing strategies across multiple product lines; Individual: Consumers are the target of brand repositioning efforts and their relevance/preferences are being addressed through product innovations
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company repositions brands to enhance relevance to consumers through marketing mix changes.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes clear organizational actions (repositioning brands, launching products, innovations) explicitly aimed at influencing individual consumers' brand perception and relevance. This represents a direct cross-scale interaction from company strategy to consumer response.

gpt5: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational] The frozen category affected the company’s North America performance.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states the frozen category affected the firm's performance, a sector-to-organization causal link. Other mentions (e.g., consumer trends) were excluded to keep within the two-scale limit and due to weaker explicit causality.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are specific people, mapped to the individual scale.; Organizational: The company (implied by 'Our performance', 'Projects') and its brands (Lean Cuisine, Hot Pockets, Coffee-mate) are single organizations or their products/units.; Environmental and Societal: The 'frozen category' represents a market condition/segment, and 'trends such as organic and ethnic' are societal norms or preferences.

These Organizational projects, in turn, are designed to enhance relevance for Individual consumers. The three distinct scales involved are clearly represented in these explicit cross-scale causal links.

Full Paragraph Text: Latin America delivered good organic growth despite a worsening of the macroeconomic situation towards the end of the year. Although consumer sentiment varied across the region, most markets did well. All Brazil’s categories grew, with Ninho in growing-up milks, KitKat in confectionery, Nesfit in biscuits and Nescau in cocoa and malt beverages making strong contributions. In Mexico the changes in fiscal legislation, pricing and subdued consumer demand affect ed the market. Nescafé Dolce Gusto delivered double-digit growth across the region, while Dog Chow and Pro Plan drove sales in the petcare business.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Macroeconomic situation, consumer sentiment, consumer demand, and fiscal legislation represent societal-level economic and regulatory systems; Organizational: Nestlé as a company with specific brands (Ninho, KitKat, Nesfit, etc.) and business performance across markets
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Macroeconomic conditions and fiscal changes affected company market performance across Latin America.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how societal-level factors (macroeconomic situation, consumer sentiment, fiscal legislation, consumer demand) explicitly influenced organizational performance. The company's brand performance is presented as responding to these external pressures, particularly in Mexico where fiscal and demand changes 'affected the market.'
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Changes in fiscal legislation are government/policy-level conditions.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: ‘The market’ refers to the sector-wide market conditions in Mexico.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal | Inter-Organizational / Sector] Fiscal legislation changes in Mexico affected the market.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states that fiscal legislation changes affected the market, a cross-scale causal link from societal policy to sector dynamics. Other statements describe performance contributions or demand/pricing without clear cross-scale causality, so they were excluded.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumer sentiment and demand are influenced by individual consumers.; Organizational: Brands like Nescafé and Dog Chow represent organizational actors driving market performance.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumer sentiment impacts brand performance in Latin America, driving growth despite macroeconomic challenges.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link between individual consumer sentiment and organizational brand performance is explicitly stated, showing how consumer behavior affects market outcomes. Only two scales are involved, focusing on individual consumers and organizational brands.
gemini2.5: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: No explicit individual actors or actions causing cross-scale effects.; Organizational: Specific brands/products (e.g., Ninho, KitKat, Dog Chow, Pro Plan, Nescafé Dolce Gusto) representing the performance of a single company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Product categories (e.g., Brazil’s categories, growing-up milks, confectionery) and business sectors (e.g., petcare business), which represent systems or collaborations among organizations or an industry segment.; Environmental and Societal: Broader systems and conditions (e.g., Latin America region, macroeconomic situation, fiscal legislation, consumer demand, the market) that affect or describe national or regional systems.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Specific brands' strong contributions and sales efforts led to growth and sales increases in their respective product categories and business sectors.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links the performance of specific brands (Organizational scale) to the growth and sales within broader product categories or business sectors (Inter-Organizational / Sector scale). For example, Ninho and KitKat 'making strong contributions' to 'All Brazil’s categories grew', and Dog Chow and Pro Plan 'drove sales in the petcare business'. While Environmental and Societal factors like macroeconomic situation and fiscal legislation are mentioned, their stated causal effects are on other Environmental and Societal elements (e.g., market), thus not qualifying as cross-scale in this context. Only two distinct scales were involved in the extracted causal links, well within the limit.

Full Paragraph Text: Relative to the market this was good growth, driven by innovation and premiumisation. The European trading en vironment continued to be volatile and intense, with defla tionary pressure increasing during the year and consumer confidence very fragile, reducing the flexibility to price.

Full Paragraph Text: The slower growth in the Zone was due to our largest market China and to Oceania. In China we needed to adapt our portfolio to reconnect with the fast-changing expectations of the Chinese consumer. Therefore, in addition to correcting trade stocks throughout the year, we focused on innovation, on reformulation and on re-launches, particularly in coffee, ready-to-drink and confectionery. We continued to see good performances in ambient culinary, ice cream and ready-to drink coffee. In Oceania we are focused on developing new trade channels.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Chinese consumers with fast-changing expectations who influence company decisions; Organizational: The company that adapts its portfolio, focuses on innovation, and develops new trade channels in response
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Chinese consumer expectations drive company portfolio adaptation and innovation focus.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states the company needed to adapt its portfolio to reconnect with fast-changing Chinese consumer expectations, showing clear causality from individual consumers to organizational strategy changes.

Full Paragraph Text: Strong growth continued in most other emerging markets, in particular the Philippines, South Asia, the Indochina region, Turkey and many markets in Africa. We introduced new premium noodles in Singapore and Malaysia. In the Philippines the new fortified Bear Brand milk powders were well received. Maggi created a new breakfast option for the Indian market, Maggi Oats Noodles, and Nestlé Milo Activ-Go was launched in parts of South East Asia. It was also rolled out in Africa, helping to deliver good growth across the continent.

While the preference is for goods concerning the environment and people, those are described as attributes of the goods and not direct causal actors influencing the organization in this specific sentence, hence only the Individual -> Organizational link is identified.

Full Paragraph Text: Our entire business would rely on increasingly rare and expensive raw materials, pushing up our costs. Without more efficient use of energy our production costs would increase while we would miss considerable savings from more sustainable packaging and less waste.

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how environmental resource constraints (rare materials) directly cause organizational cost increases. The efficiency improvements mentioned are potential organizational responses but lack explicit causal language connecting them to external forces.

o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph discusses internal business challenges without indicating explicit causal links across different hierarchical scales.

Other statements describe internal organizational actions (e.g., energy use, packaging) leading to internal organizational outcomes (e.g., increased costs, missed savings), which are not cross-scale interactions. Only two distinct scales were identified and used for the link.

Full Paragraph Text: We would also risk the disapproval of governments, regulators and NGOs, and our brands – Unilever’s crown jewels – could suffer reputational damage, representing serious economic loss to the business.

The risk of disapproval leading to reputational damage and economic loss represents clear cross-scale influence from societal institutions to the company level.

Full Paragraph Text: Tough economic and financial headwinds with continued competitive intensity made 2014 one of the most challenging years that the industry and Unilever have faced for some time. A slowdown in the growth of emerging markets proved a testing environment while consumers in developed markets continued to show caution. Volatile currencies were a further negative.

gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] Societal economic headwinds made 2014 especially challenging for Unilever.

These direct causal statements connect three distinct hierarchical scales as per the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: However, Unilever’s business model and strategy proved robust, delivering a competitive performance with underlying sales growth ahead of the market and solid margin expansion. Our growth model is based on a leaner, more agile Unilever and consistency of delivery in this more volatile market is key. The Boards remain convinced that a clear, purpose-driven business model is the best way for Unilever to continue generating sustainable, long-term returns for all stakeholders, including our shareholders, as proved by a year of strong, dependable cash flow and steadily increasing dividends. The full year dividend paid in 2014 rose to €1.12, a 7% increase on 2013.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph describes Unilever's business performance, strategy, and financial outcomes but does not establish any explicit causal relationships between different scales. The text focuses on organizational-level results (sales growth, margins, dividends) without describing how actors at one scale causally influence actors at another scale.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever and its Boards are a single company and its governing body.; Individual: Shareholders are people receiving dividends/returns.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever’s model delivers returns to shareholders via increased dividends.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Unilever’s model generates returns for shareholders, confirmed by higher dividends. No other clear cross-scale causal effects are stated beyond this organizational-to-individual influence.

gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual

gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] A volatile market influences an organization's delivery strategy, while its business model generates returns for individual stakeholders.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details two cross-scale interactions. Firstly, the 'more volatile market' (Environmental and Societal) dictates the importance of 'consistency of delivery' for Unilever (Organizational). Secondly, Unilever's 'purpose-driven business model' (Organizational) is directly credited with 'generating sustainable, long-term returns for all stakeholders, including our shareholders' (Individual).

Full Paragraph Text: In China we undertook large capital expenditure, building a new dry savoury plant and a new washing powder factory. In Indonesia, large-scale capital investment was made in Siliwangi, creating a plant for Cikarang Foods, adding significant capacity to dry and wet savoury production. In the Philippines a new dry savoury factory was built. Detergent and ice cream factories were built in Africa.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes capital expenditure and factory construction activities across multiple countries, but does not identify specific actors or establish causal relationships between different organizational scales. All activities appear to be undertaken by the same organizational entity without explicit cross-scale interactions.
