o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as Unilever's organizational actions in logistics and marketing directly affect individual consumers' access to products. No other distinct scales were present.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Environmental and Societal -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: 'consumers' are specific people making purchasing decisions.; Organizational: 'Our logistics operations' and 'our go-to-market teams' refer to parts of Unilever (a single organization), and 'retailers' are individual companies.; Environmental and Societal: 'sales channels', 'stores', and 'e-commerce channel' refer to broad market systems or infrastructure for product distribution, not specific organizations.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's teams influence market channels which, in turn, enable consumers to purchase products.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how Unilever's 'go-to-market teams' (Organizational) strategically place products into 'sales channels' (Environmental and Societal). These channels then serve as the means 'for consumers to buy' (Individual), establishing a clear causal chain across these three distinct hierarchical scales. The language used (e.g., 'ensure', 'for ... to buy') strongly indicates direct causal influence.

Full Paragraph Text: We make the majority of what we sell through a network of more than 240 manufacturing sites around the world. We have invested significantly in our factories in recent years to create an efficient, reliable and more sustainable network. We are now able to maximise the global scale of our operations, while having the agility to meet local demands. More eco-efficient production is helping us meet the USLP targets, so by the end of January 2015, for instance, all our factories had achieved zero non-hazardous waste to landfill, producing 140,000 tonnes less waste. Since 2008, we estimate that eco-production has avoided costs in excess of €400 million.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('We') as a single entity making investments, setting targets, and implementing eco-efficient production practices; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The network of more than 240 manufacturing sites around the world represents a multi-organizational manufacturing system
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational] Company investments in factories create efficient, sustainable manufacturing network achieving waste reduction targets.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how organizational-level investments and decisions by the company directly transformed their inter-organizational manufacturing network, enabling global scale operations and sustainability achievements. The causality is explicit through the investment-outcome relationship.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('we'), its factories, operations, and USLP targets are one organization.; Environmental and Societal: Landfill and waste reductions impact ecosystems/environmental outcomes.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Company’s eco-efficient production eliminated non-hazardous landfill waste, cutting 140,000 tonnes.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links company actions (eco-efficient production, zero waste to landfill) to environmental outcomes (less waste to landfill). Other statements concern internal efficiency/costs or capabilities, not cross-scale causality, so they were excluded.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The text discusses the company's manufacturing sites and their operations.; Environmental and Societal: The text references the USLP targets and the impact of eco-efficient production on waste reduction.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The company's eco-efficient production practices influence environmental targets.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the company's actions in eco-production directly contribute to meeting environmental targets, demonstrating a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: 'We' refers to a single company. 'Our factories', 'eco-efficient production', and 'USLP targets' are internal components, processes, or goals of this single organization.; Environmental and Societal: 'Local demands' represent the needs and expectations arising from local communities or the broader societal context.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] An organization's agility allows it to meet the demands of the local societal environment.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The explicit cross-scale interaction identified is the Organizational level's ability to respond to Environmental and Societal 'local demands'. The company (Organizational) actively develops 'agility' to 'meet' these demands, demonstrating a direct causal influence. Other interactions discussed within the paragraph, such as investments in factories or achieving USLP targets through eco-production, primarily occur within the Organizational scale.

Full Paragraph Text: How we move products from factories to customers is the role of our logistics operation. We are now rolling out our global network of logistics centres that organise movement of goods centrally and more efficiently, delivering savings, reduced stocks, reduced carbon emissions and improved customer service. These operational hubs now allow us to centralise other services too, including monitoring orders from customers through to payment.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company implementing global logistics network and operational changes; Individual: Customers receiving improved service and having their orders monitored
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company's global logistics network rollout improves customer service delivery.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how the company's organizational changes (rolling out global logistics centers) directly cause improvements for individual customers (better service, order monitoring). This represents a clear cross-scale causal relationship from organizational operations to individual customer experience.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company's logistics operation/network of logistics centres taking centralized actions; Environmental and Societal: Reduced carbon emissions are environmental-level outcomes
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Centralized logistics reduces the organization's carbon emissions footprint.
gpt5: Rationale: The text states the organization’s logistics rollout causes reduced carbon emissions, a cross-scale effect. A potential Organizational -> Individual link (improved customer service) was omitted to keep within the scale limit.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The logistics operation and logistics centres represent a formal internal unit that organizes the movement of goods.; Individual: Customers are specific people who receive the products and are affected by the logistics operation.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The logistics operation enhances customer service by efficiently moving products to customers.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the logistics operation (Organizational) directly impacts how products are delivered to customers (Individual), demonstrating a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'customers' who receive products, experience improved service, and place 'orders'.; Organizational: Refers to the company ('We'), its 'logistics operation', 'factories' (as part of its supply network), 'global network of logistics centres', and 'operational hubs' that implement and manage these systems.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] The company's logistics operation and network of centres deliver products to, improve service for, and monitor orders from individual customers.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how an Organizational actor (the company's logistics operation, centres, and hubs) causally influences Individual actors (customers). All identified cross-scale links describe an Organizational -> Individual influence, such as moving products to customers, improving their service, and monitoring their orders. Only two distinct scales (Organizational, Individual) were identified, well within the limit of three.

Full Paragraph Text: We work closely with retailers to win in the market place and make sure that our brands are always available, properly displayed and in the right price bracket. Our go-to-market capability ensures that we become the supplier of choice for our customers and trade partners, through strong joint business planning and in-store execution via Perfect Store programmes, to help deliver sustainable sales growth. This is essential for us to be able to add premium brand extensions to our product ranges, land product innovations on the shelves, enter new geographies and markets, and build our distribution strength to reach new consumers.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('we') implementing go-to-market strategies, Perfect Store programmes, and brand extensions; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Retailers, customers, and trade partners that the company works with through joint business planning and distribution networks
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational] Company's go-to-market strategies influence retailer partnerships and distribution networks.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes how the company (Organizational) uses specific strategies and programs to influence and work with retailers and trade partners (Inter-Organizational). The causality flows from the company's capabilities to the broader retail ecosystem relationships.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: Collaboration with retailers, customers, and trade partners via joint business planning and in-store execution; Organizational: The company’s outcomes like sustainable sales growth and supplier-of-choice status
gpt5: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational] Collaboration with retailers drives the company’s sustainable sales growth.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties cross-organization collaboration (with retailers, joint planning, in-store execution) to the company’s growth. To keep scales ≤2, only the inter-org to organizational causal link is included.
o4_mini: Links: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The text refers to a specific organization working with retailers.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The collaboration with retailers and trade partners indicates inter-organizational interactions.; Individual: The mention of reaching new consumers implies individual-level interactions.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Individual] The organization influences inter-organizational relationships, which in turn affect individual consumers.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links are based on explicit causal relationships described in the text, where the organization's actions with retailers lead to broader inter-organizational impacts that ultimately reach individual consumers.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: This scale represents the core company ('We', 'us', 'our') and its internal capabilities ('go-to-market capability', 'distribution strength', 'sustainable sales growth'), as well as its direct partners considered as single entities ('retailers', 'customers', 'trade partners').; Environmental and Societal: This scale captures broader societal systems and contexts, specifically 'new geographies and markets' which represent areas of macro-level expansion.; Individual: This scale refers to 'new consumers,' who are specific people targeted by the company's efforts.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Individual] Organizational growth and distribution efforts enable expansion into new markets and directly impact individual consumers.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph details how the company's (Organizational) sustainable sales growth is essential for its expansion into new geographies and markets (Environmental and Societal). Furthermore, the company's organizational effort to build distribution strength directly leads to reaching new consumers (Individual). The Inter-Organizational scale, though present with 'joint business planning,' was omitted to adhere to the 3-scale limit, prioritizing the company's direct outcomes and their cross-scale impact.

Full Paragraph Text: We spend about €7 billion annually on marketing, making us one of the world’s biggest advertisers. This ensures that our brands and products are consumers’ first choice. We use multiple media to achieve cut-through in a highly competitive and busy world. Traditional media channels continue to play a big part but digital communications have revolutionised the way marketing engages with people, creating entirely new sales and marketing opportunities. We create our own entertainment content, including Unilever brand advertising, and this is distributed, for example, by mobile devices in emerging markets.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company spending €7 billion on marketing and creating content; Individual: Consumers making brand choices and people engaging with marketing content
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company's massive marketing investment directly influences consumer brand preferences.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how Unilever's organizational marketing strategy (€7 billion spend, content creation, multi-media approach) is explicitly designed to causally influence individual consumers' choices. The company states this marketing 'ensures that our brands and products are consumers' first choice,' establishing clear cross-scale causality from organizational action to individual behavior.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: “We” refers to Unilever acting as a single company spending on marketing and creating content.; Individual: “Consumers” refers to individual people making purchase choices.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company marketing spend ensures consumers choose its brands.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states that the company's marketing spend ensures consumers select its brands, a direct org-to-individual effect. Other statements (media, digital communications) lack explicit cross-scale causality.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company is making strategic marketing decisions.; Individual: Consumers are influenced by the marketing efforts.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The company's marketing strategies directly influence consumer preferences.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the company's marketing efforts are explicitly stated to ensure that their brands are the first choice for consumers, demonstrating a clear causal influence from Organizational to Individual.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Includes 'consumers' and 'people', representing specific individuals making choices or being engaged.; Organizational: Refers to 'We' (the company), its 'marketing' function, 'brands and products', 'entertainment content', and 'Unilever brand advertising'.; Environmental and Societal: Encompasses 'multiple media' channels (traditional, digital communications) and 'mobile devices' as broader communication systems and infrastructure.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] Organizational marketing influences individual consumer choice and engagement, while societal digital communication systems revolutionize organizational marketing and facilitate content distribution.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how the Organizational level (the company's marketing efforts) directly influences the Individual level (consumers' choices and engagement). Conversely, Environmental and Societal factors, such as digital communications and mobile devices, are shown to cause significant changes within the Organizational level by revolutionizing marketing approaches and enabling content distribution. All identified links are explicitly stated and cross different scales. The three scales (Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal) cover all relevant actors and interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s portfolio has four categories: Personal Care, Foods, Refreshment and Home Care. We have 13 brands with sales of more than €1 billion. Brands are our biggest asset but also present a risk if they do not maintain value and relevance to consumers. That’s why innovation and remaining competitive are crucial. We launched new brands in 2014, backed by marketing and customer insight, for example Regenerate, a dental care product. In addition to the Qinyuan and Talenti Gelato & Sorbetto acquisitions, we are also in the process of acquiring the Camay and Zest brands, to expand categories and boost growth. To sharpen our portfolio in 2014 we disposed of Slim. Fast, Ragu and Bertolli in North America, and other non-core Foods brands.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever's internal business activities including brand portfolio management, acquisitions, disposals, and product launches. While it mentions consumers as a consideration for brand relevance, there is no explicit causal relationship described between different organizational scales - all actions are taken by Unilever as a single organizational entity managing its own operations.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are referenced as the arbiters of value and relevance.; Organizational: Unilever’s brands and portfolio decisions concern organizational entities.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumers’ perceptions determine brands’ risk/value within Unilever.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly ties consumer relevance to brand risk, establishing Individual -> Organizational causality. Other actions (launches, acquisitions, disposals) describe intra-organizational moves without explicit cross-scale effects.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company is making strategic decisions that affect its brand portfolio.; Individual: Consumers are influenced by the brands and their relevance, impacting their purchasing decisions.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever's brand strategies impact consumer relevance and purchasing behavior.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as Unilever's organizational decisions regarding brand innovation and acquisitions directly affect individual consumer choices. Only two scales were relevant, focusing on the organizational actions and their impact on individuals.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are specific people whose perception of value and relevance is explicitly stated as critical for brands.; Organizational: Unilever is a company; its 'brands' are internal units or assets managed by the company, hence they are mapped to Organizational scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumers' perception of brand value directly influences the risk profile of organizational brands.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links the risk of brands (Organizational) to their failure to maintain value and relevance to consumers (Individual). This highlights a direct causal influence where individual consumer perception impacts the organizational entity's stability. Only Individual and Organizational scales were involved in this interaction.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s products sell in more than 190 countries and are used by 2 billion consumers every day. Our business is organised across three geographies: the Americas; Europe; and markets comprising Asia, Australasia, Africa, Middle East, Turkey, Russia, Ukraine and Belarus. We also analyse operations by developed and emerging markets. This wide spread exposes us to economic and political risks beyond our control. However, the diversity of our portfolio and geographic reach help mitigate our exposure to any specific risk.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever's organizational structure, geographic presence, and risk exposure but does not establish any explicit causal relationships between different scales. While it mentions consumers (Individual scale) and the company's operations (Organizational scale), there is no stated causality - only descriptive information about market presence and risk mitigation through diversification.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever’s organizational spread and portfolio mitigating its exposure to broader economic/political risks but does not state a direct causal effect across different scales. Effects are framed as the organization changing its own exposure, not causing or being caused by societal-level actions.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph discusses Unilever's operations and risks but does not provide explicit causal links between different hierarchical scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual:  'consumers' refers to specific people using products.; Organizational:  'Unilever' is explicitly named as a single company.; Environmental and Societal:  'economic and political risks' represent societal-level systems and external forces (e.g., governments, capital markets).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Unilever's products, an output of the organizational scale, are directly used by individual consumers.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The only explicit cross-scale causal link identified is between Unilever (Organizational) and consumers (Individual), as Unilever's products are actively 'used by' them. While the Environmental and Societal scale (economic and political risks) is mentioned, the text describes how organizational attributes (wide spread, diversity) influence Unilever's *exposure to* or *mitigation of* these risks, rather than stating a direct A -> B causal influence from or to this scale.

Full Paragraph Text: We cannot achieve our Vision to double our size unless we find new ways to operate that decouple growth from our environmental impact, while using growth as an enabler for positive social impact. Launched in 2010, the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) is our blueprint for sustainable growth. It is helping to drive profitable growth for our brands, save costs and fuel innovation.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company with its Sustainable Living Plan, growth strategy, and brand operations; Environmental and Societal: Environmental impact and social impact systems that the company seeks to influence through its operations
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's sustainable growth plan aims to decouple business growth from environmental impact while enabling positive social impact.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever (Organizational scale) implementing a strategic plan that explicitly targets environmental and social systems (Environmental and Societal scale). The causality is clear through the company's intentional decoupling strategy and use of growth to enable positive impacts.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The text describes Unilever’s internal plan driving brand growth, cost savings, and innovation—all within the organizational scale. References to environmental and social impact are aspirational, not explicit causal links.
o4_mini: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific organization implementing strategies.; Environmental and Societal: The environmental impact and social impact relate to broader societal systems.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's strategies link organizational growth to environmental and social impacts.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links demonstrate how Unilever's organizational strategies are influenced by and aim to influence environmental and societal factors. The focus on sustainable growth connects these scales explicitly.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, 'we', 'our brands', and the 'Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP)' represent a single company and its internal initiatives/units.; Environmental and Societal: 'Environmental impact' and 'social impact' refer to broad societal-level and ecosystem-level outcomes, not specific organizations or individuals.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's organizational growth and operations are explicitly stated to influence both environmental and social impacts.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes two clear cross-scale causal links where the Organizational scale (Unilever's growth and operations) impacts the Environmental and Societal scale (environmental and social outcomes). Only two distinct scales were identified with explicit interactions, thus the scale limitation is not an issue.

Full Paragraph Text: The USLP sets out three big, ambitious goals. Underpinning these goals are nine commitments supported by targets spanning our social and environmental performance.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes the structure of the USLP (goals, commitments, targets) but contains no actors taking actions that causally influence other actors across different scales. It is purely descriptive of a framework's components without any cross-scale interactions.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The text describes goals, commitments, and targets of an organizational plan but does not state any causal influence across different scales.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph does not provide any explicit causal influence between actors at different scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes the internal structure and scope of 'The USLP' (Organizational scale), mentioning its goals, commitments, and targets. While 'social and environmental performance' touches upon the Environmental and Societal scale, the text only states that targets 'span' or 'cover' this performance, not that they explicitly cause or are caused by interactions with it across scales. No explicit cross-scale causal links are present.

Full Paragraph Text: We are making good progress with our first goal: to help more than a billion people improve their health and well-being by 2020, reaching 397 million by the end of 2014. The progress on our second goal is more mixed. We have achieved zero non-hazardous waste to landfill from our factories, and continue to make significant reductions in the greenhouse gas (GHG) and water impacts of our manufacturing. But the consumer element of our target to halve the water and GHG impacts of our products remains a challenge. On waste reduction, new technology such as the roll-out of compressed deodorant sprays and our new Dove Body Wash bottles has enabled reductions. On our third goal, we are also making good progress. We are now sourcing more than half our agricultural raw materials sustainably and have reached around 800,000 smallholder farmers with help and training. We have created 70,000 women micro-entrepreneurs distributing our products in India while making progress on our new commitments to enhance livelihoods across the value chain.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Smallholder farmers receiving help and training, women micro-entrepreneurs distributing products, and consumers using products; Organizational: The company implementing sustainability goals, manufacturing changes, and sourcing policies
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company reaches smallholder farmers with training and creates women micro-entrepreneurs for product distribution.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes explicit organizational actions that directly impact individuals - providing help and training to farmers, and creating micro-entrepreneur opportunities for women. These represent clear cross-scale causality from organizational initiatives to individual outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('we') undertakes programs, product roll-outs, and sourcing policies.; Individual: Smallholder farmers and women micro-entrepreneurs are specific people impacted.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The company’s programs trained farmers and created women micro-entrepreneurs.
gpt5: Rationale: Explicit statements show organizational actions causing outcomes for individuals (training farmers; creating micro-entrepreneurs). To keep ≤2 scales, environmental links were omitted despite being suggested.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: The mention of smallholder farmers and women micro-entrepreneurs indicates individual actors.; Organizational: The reference to factories and product manufacturing represents organizational actions.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The organization is impacting individuals by training farmers and creating micro-entrepreneurs.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links are drawn from the organization's actions that directly influence individual actors, such as smallholder farmers and women micro-entrepreneurs. The focus is on these two scales as they represent clear causal relationships.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Individual -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to specific people (billion people, smallholder farmers, women micro-entrepreneurs) or informal groups (consumer element).; Organizational: Refers to 'We' (the company), its internal units (factories, manufacturing), and its products and technology.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to the 'value chain', which encompasses systems and collaborations among multiple organizations.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational] The organization actively helps individuals, supports smallholder farmers, creates entrepreneurs, and enhances value chain livelihoods, though consumer behavior presents challenges.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how the Organizational entity ('We') exerts causal influence on Individual actors (people, farmers, entrepreneurs) through direct help, training, and creation. It also shows a causal influence on the Inter-Organizational / Sector level by 'enhancing livelihoods across the value chain'. Conversely, the 'consumer element' (Individual scale) is identified as a challenge to the Organizational target, indicating a causal impediment. These interactions clearly span three distinct hierarchical scales.

Full Paragraph Text: By 2020 we will help more than a billion people take action to improve their health and well-being.
claude4: Rationale: This statement is a future commitment or goal without describing any explicit causal relationships between actors at different scales. While it mentions helping people (Individual scale), there is no clear actor identified who will do the helping, nor any explicit causal mechanism described.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: 'We' refers to a single entity making a commitment to act.; Individual: More than a billion people who will take action on their health.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] An organization commits to help over a billion people take health-improving actions.
gpt5: Rationale: The sentence explicitly states that an organizational actor ('we') will help individuals take action, a direct cross-scale causal influence. No other scales are mentioned, so only this link is included.
o4_mini: Rationale: The statement does not provide explicit causal links between different hierarchical scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: 'we' represents a single entity (e.g., a company, NGO) making a commitment.; Individual: 'a billion people' refers to specific individuals.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] An organizational entity helps individuals take action to improve their health and well-being.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states a causal link from an Organizational actor ('we') to Individual actors ('a billion people'). The organization's action is to 'help' the individuals, demonstrating a direct cross-scale influence. Only two scales were involved, well within the limit.

Full Paragraph Text: By 2020 our goal is to halve the environmental footprint of the making and use of our products as we grow our business.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph states a goal or intention but does not describe any explicit causal interactions between actors at different scales. It mentions 'our goal' but provides no information about who the actor is, what actions they will take, or how different organizational levels will interact to achieve this environmental target.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: A company states its goal for its business and products.; Environmental and Societal: The environmental footprint is an environmental impact at societal/ecosystem level.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] A company’s stated goal aims to halve its products’ environmental footprint.
gpt5: Rationale: The statement explicitly ties an organization’s actions to reduced environmental footprint, indicating intended causal influence. No other scales are implicated with explicit causal links.
o4_mini: Rationale: The statement does not provide explicit causal links between different hierarchical scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph states a goal ('our goal is to halve the environmental footprint') set by an Organizational actor ('our business') related to an Environmental and Societal outcome ('environmental footprint'). However, it does not describe an explicit causal influence or mechanism by which the Organizational actor's actions lead to the environmental outcome. It is a statement of intent, not a direct causal link between different scales as defined by the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: By 2020 we will enhance the livelihoods of millions of people as we grow our business.
claude4: Rationale: This statement is a future-oriented goal or commitment without explicit causal mechanisms. While it mentions business growth and enhancing livelihoods, it does not specify concrete actors or describe explicit causal relationships between different scales of operation.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: “We” refers to a business committing to action.; Individual: “Millions of people” refers to individuals whose livelihoods are affected.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Business growth will enhance the livelihoods of millions of people.
gpt5: Rationale: The sentence explicitly ties the organization’s business growth to improving individuals’ livelihoods. Only two scales are involved, forming a single cross-scale causal link.
o4_mini: Rationale: The statement does not provide explicit causal links between different scales; it only mentions enhancing livelihoods without specifying how this relates to organizational actions.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: 'we' refers to a single company/organization that will grow its business.; Individual: 'millions of people' represent specific individuals whose livelihoods will be enhanced.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Organizational growth directly enhances the livelihoods of millions of people.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states a causal link where the action of 'growing our business' (Organizational scale, represented by 'we') leads to 'enhance the livelihoods of millions of people' (Individual scale). This establishes a clear cross-scale interaction. Only two distinct scales were identified.

Full Paragraph Text: By 2020 we will help more than a billion people to improve their health and hygiene. This will help reduce the incidence of life-threatening diseases like diarrhoea.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a future goal and its expected outcome but does not identify any specific actors or explicit causal mechanisms. It lacks concrete entities taking actions that would create cross-scale interactions.
gpt5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Individual -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: “We” commits to helping people, indicating an organization acting.; Individual: “More than a billion people” are the recipients changing health/hygiene behaviors.; Environmental and Societal: “Reduce the incidence of life-threatening diseases” refers to population-level outcomes.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] An organization helps individuals improve hygiene, which in turn lowers disease incidence at the societal level.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states organizational assistance causing changes in individual health/hygiene. It also states this leads to reduced disease incidence, a societal outcome. Hence two cross-scale causal links are warranted.

gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Individual -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: 'more than a billion people' refers to specific individuals as recipients of aid and agents of health improvement.; Organizational: 'we' implies a single organization (e.g., a company or NGO) making a pledge and taking action.; Environmental and Societal: 'the incidence of life-threatening diseases' represents a population-level health outcome, affecting society at large.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] An organization's aid to individuals improves their health, which then contributes to reducing societal disease incidence.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph details a clear causal chain involving three distinct scales. An Organizational actor ('we') directly influences Individuals ('a billion people'). In turn, the improved health of these Individuals then leads to a positive impact on the Environmental and Societal scale by reducing disease incidence. All three identified scales are explicitly linked in this sequence, with 'help' and 'will help reduce' serving as explicit causal verbs.

This directly links an action from the Organizational scale to an outcome at the Environmental and Societal scale. Only two scales are explicitly involved in this causal relationship.

Full Paragraph Text: World population is expected to rise to 8 billion by 2025 and, by then, more than 4 billion will be part of the ‘consuming class’. For the first time the number of people with discretionary income will exceed the number struggling to meet basic needs – a trend described by management consultancy McKinsey as possibly the biggest opportunity in the history of capitalism.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph presents demographic projections and trends but lacks explicit causal relationships between actors at different scales. While it mentions population growth, the 'consuming class', and McKinsey's assessment, there are no concrete actors taking actions that causally influence actors at other scales - only statistical forecasts and observations about market opportunities.

The mention of McKinsey (Organizational) describing this trend is an observation, not a direct causal interaction where one scale's actions or state influences another's state or actions.

claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumer health concerns drive FMCG companies to adapt product development.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly states that FMCG product development is 'reacting to' consumers' health concerns, establishing explicit causality from individual consumers to organizational product development activities.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are specific people whose concerns are cited.; Organizational: FMCG product development refers to company teams/functions adjusting products.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumers’ health concerns cause FMCG product development teams to react.
gpt5: Rationale: The sentence explicitly ties consumers’ concerns to actions by product development, indicating causality. This is a cross-scale link from individuals to organizational teams; no other scales are mentioned.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are individuals concerned about health.; Organizational: FMCG product development is an organizational activity.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumers' health concerns drive FMCG product development.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as consumers' health concerns explicitly influence the actions of FMCG organizations in product development.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers refer to specific people, mapping to the Individual scale.; Organizational: FMCG product development represents a function within a single company or organization, mapping to the Organizational scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumers' concerns about health and well-being are causing FMCG product development to react.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states a causal relationship where consumers' (Individual scale) concerns influence FMCG product development (Organizational scale). This establishes a clear cross-scale interaction. Only two distinct scales were identified.

Full Paragraph Text: Malnutrition – under and over nutrition – is an issue affecting the industry in both emerging and developed markets. This is creating a trend toward the manufacture of healthier food products, which either have fortified ingredients to improve dietary quality or address other dietary-related complaints such as unhealthy cholesterol levels.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition affecting both emerging and developed markets represents a societal-level health issue across different regions and populations; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The food industry as a whole responding by manufacturing healthier products represents sector-level action across multiple organizations
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Societal malnutrition issues drive food industry to manufacture healthier products.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly establishes causality where a societal health problem (malnutrition) is driving industry-wide behavioral change in product manufacturing. This represents a clear cross-scale interaction from societal conditions to sector-level response.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition is a societal-level health issue.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: ‘The industry’ and an industry-wide trend indicate sector-level dynamics.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Malnutrition drives an industry trend toward manufacturing healthier food products.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states that malnutrition affects the industry and creates a sector-wide trend. It does not explicitly state firm-level actions beyond this trend, so only a societal-to-sector link is included.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: The food industry is responding to malnutrition trends.; Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition is a societal issue affecting populations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Malnutrition influences the food industry to create healthier products.
o4_mini: Rationale: The text explicitly states that malnutrition affects the industry, indicating a causal influence from the societal level to the inter-organizational level. No other distinct scales were present.
gemini2.5: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition, a broad societal health issue affecting populations across markets.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to 'the industry' and 'a trend' as collective phenomena or patterns across multiple organizations within the food sector.; Organizational: The 'manufacture' of healthier food products is an action undertaken by individual companies (organizations).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational] Societal malnutrition creates a trend in the food industry, influencing individual organizations to manufacture healthier products.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph outlines a causal chain where malnutrition (Environmental and Societal) explicitly 'creates a trend' within the food industry (Inter-Organizational / Sector). This sector-wide trend then strongly implies an influence on the specific 'manufacture' actions of individual companies (Organizational). All identified links involve different hierarchical scales as per the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: Women play a pivotal role in the FMCG market, controlling the majority of purchasing decisions. The promotion of women’s rights and opportunities has clear long-term implications for the FMCG market in terms of product development and innovation. Significant developments such as the UN’s new Sustainable Development Goals are expected to accelerate these opportunities.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: UN's Sustainable Development Goals represent a societal-level policy framework that influences broader systems; Inter-Organizational / Sector: FMCG market represents a sector-wide system involving multiple organizations and their collective product development and innovation activities
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] UN's SDGs expected to accelerate FMCG market opportunities for product development.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph establishes a clear causal link where UN's Sustainable Development Goals (societal-level policy) are expected to accelerate opportunities in the FMCG market (sector-level). While women's purchasing power is mentioned, no explicit causal mechanism is described between individual women and other scales.
gpt5: Scales: Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector
gpt5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The UN’s new Sustainable Development Goals are a single organization’s initiative.; Environmental and Societal: Promotion of women’s rights and opportunities reflects societal-level policies and norms.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The FMCG market is a sector involving multiple organizations.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] UN SDGs boost women’s rights opportunities, which in turn shape FMCG sector product development and innovation.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states societal promotion of women’s rights influences the FMCG market, and that UN SDGs accelerate these societal opportunities. We include two cross-scale causal links forming a chain from UN to society to the sector.
o4_mini: Links: Individual -> Organizational | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as consumers making purchasing decisions.; Organizational: FMCG market as a specific industry.; Environmental and Societal: UN's Sustainable Development Goals impacting societal norms and opportunities.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Women influence FMCG market decisions, shaped by societal goals like the UN's SDGs.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links demonstrate how individual women's purchasing power affects organizational product strategies, while societal-level initiatives like the UN's SDGs create broader opportunities for the FMCG sector.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: 'Women' refers to specific people or informal groups.; Environmental and Societal: 'FMCG market' is an economic system/sector. 'Promotion of women’s rights and opportunities' and 'UN’s new Sustainable Development Goals' represent societal trends and global norms/frameworks, respectively.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] Women's individual purchasing decisions directly influence the broader FMCG market's dynamics.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The only explicit cross-scale interaction identified is from Individual (women) to Environmental and Societal (FMCG market), as women's control over purchasing decisions directly shapes the market. While the UN is Organizational, its 'Sustainable Development Goals' are classified as Environmental and Societal due to their nature as global norms/frameworks; therefore, their influence on 'opportunities' (also Environmental and Societal) constitutes a same-scale interaction. Similarly, the influence of 'promotion of women’s rights' (Environmental and Societal) on the 'FMCG market' (Environmental and Societal) is also a same-scale interaction.

Full Paragraph Text: FMCG advertising is rapidly migrating to digital platforms, driven by the take-up of smartphones and tablets. Global digital advertising is estimated at US $137.5 billion, or a quarter of total advertising spend.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes trends and correlations (FMCG advertising migrating to digital platforms, driven by smartphone/tablet adoption) but lacks explicit actors taking causal actions across different scales. No specific entities are identified as causing changes to other entities at different hierarchical levels.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: People adopting smartphones/tablets ('take-up').; Inter-Organizational / Sector: FMCG advertising as a sector shifting to digital platforms.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Consumer device adoption drives FMCG advertising’s shift to digital.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties consumer device uptake to a sector-level shift in FMCG advertising. The spending figure is descriptive and does not state causality, so no additional links.
o4_mini: Rationale: No explicit causal influence across different scales is present in the text.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to specific people adopting smartphones and tablets ('take-up').; Inter-Organizational / Sector: FMCG advertising represents industry-wide activity and strategies across many organizations within the sector. Digital platforms are shared infrastructures used by these organizations.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Individual adoption of smartphones and tablets drives a sector-wide migration of FMCG advertising to digital platforms.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states one cross-scale causal link: the 'take-up' by individuals of mobile devices 'drives' a shift in 'FMCG advertising' which is a sector-level activity. The second sentence provides statistics about global digital advertising but does not describe any causal interactions across scales.

Full Paragraph Text: The trend is being driven in developed and also emerging markets where mobile phones are proving to be one of the most effective ways of delivering advertising to individuals, particularly in the most remote rural locations. For instance, large parts of rural India have no, or very limited, access to television, print or radio. However, mobile phone penetration and usage is high. As a result, Unilever has launched Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station in India, which delivers radio content to mobile phones through the simple mechanism of giving a missed call.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific company that launched a mobile radio station service; Individual: People in rural locations who receive advertising content through mobile phones via missed calls
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever delivers advertising content to rural individuals through mobile radio service.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear causal relationship where Unilever (organizational scale) actively delivers advertising content to individuals in rural areas through their mobile radio station service. This represents explicit cross-scale causality from company action to individual reception of content.
gpt5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual | Environmental and Societal -> Individual
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Market conditions and infrastructure: high mobile penetration and limited TV/print/radio in rural India.; Organizational: Unilever launching the Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station.; Individual: Individuals in remote rural locations receiving advertising/content on mobile phones.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] Market media conditions drive Unilever’s mobile radio launch, which then delivers advertising content to individuals.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties rural media access and mobile penetration to Unilever’s launch, and states that mobile phones effectively deliver advertising to individuals. This yields Env/Soc -> Org and Org -> Ind, plus a direct Env/Soc -> Ind effect. Three scales are used clearly and minimally.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Individuals in rural areas are the recipients of mobile advertising.; Organizational: Unilever is an organization that is implementing a mobile radio service.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever's mobile radio service targets individuals in rural areas for advertising.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because Unilever's organizational action of launching a mobile radio service directly impacts individuals in rural India by providing them with content through their mobile phones.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Individual | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'individuals' as the specific people receiving content/advertising.; Organizational: Refers to 'Unilever' as a single company and its 'Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station' as an organizational initiative.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'mobile phones' as a widespread societal technology/infrastructure, and 'developed and emerging markets' and 'rural India' as societal-level contexts.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Societal mobile phone prevalence drives organizational action, which leverages the societal mobile phone system to reach individuals with content.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how the widespread use of mobile phones (Environmental and Societal) influences an organization's strategy (Unilever, Organizational) and how this strategy then leverages the mobile phone system to reach individuals (Individual). All three identified scales are explicitly linked with clear causal language.

Full Paragraph Text: This mobile channel provides content including Bollywood movie songs, dialogues and jokes that can be interspersed with Unilever brand advertising. Data and analytics are extensively used to vary content to make it relevant and interesting. The channel reaches approximately 10 million people without a TV in Bihar and Jharkhand states, making it one of the largest media channels in these regions. The channel had 29.5 million users by the end of December 2014, helping increase spontaneous awareness of Unilever brands.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company using the mobile channel for brand advertising and analytics; Individual: The 10 million people and 29.5 million users who consume the content and develop brand awareness
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever's mobile channel advertising increases brand awareness among millions of individual users.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how Unilever (organizational scale) uses its mobile channel to influence individual users' brand awareness. This represents a direct causal relationship from organizational marketing strategy to individual consumer awareness outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Users/people engaging with the mobile channel; Organizational: Unilever brands (brand awareness as an org-level outcome)
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Users of the channel helped increase spontaneous awareness of Unilever brands.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states that the large user base helped increase awareness of Unilever brands, a cross-scale effect from individuals to an organization. Other statements (reach, content variation) lack explicit cross-scale causal effects.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: The channel reaches individuals in Bihar and Jharkhand.; Organizational: Unilever is a brand that is advertising through the channel.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] The mobile channel influences brand awareness for Unilever among individuals in Bihar and Jharkhand.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the channel's reach to individuals directly contributes to increased awareness of Unilever brands, demonstrating a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to specific people or 'users' (10 million people, 29.5 million users) and their cognitive state ('spontaneous awareness').; Organizational: Refers to a single organization (mobile channel, Unilever brands/advertising) and its internal tools/activities ('data and analytics').; Environmental and Societal: Refers to societal-level systems (the geographical 'Bihar and Jharkhand states' and the broader 'media channels in these regions' as an industry landscape).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] An organizational mobile channel reaches and influences individuals' awareness while also impacting its position within the regional societal media landscape.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how an Organizational entity (the mobile channel) directly impacts Individual users by reaching them and increasing their brand awareness. Furthermore, the channel's operational scale also defines its standing within the broader Environmental and Societal media landscape of the regions. All identified scales and links are explicitly stated or strongly implied by causal verbs in the text.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 many consumers have faced tough conditions as economic uncertainty has held back growth around the world, both in the developed markets and in emerging markets. Meanwhile consumption continues to be linked to many of the world’s biggest problems – deforestation, climate change, water scarcity, malnutrition and unhealthy diets.
claude4: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Individual | Individual -> Environmental and Societal
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are specific people making consumption choices and facing economic conditions; Environmental and Societal: Economic uncertainty, global growth conditions, and systemic problems like climate change and deforestation represent societal-level systems
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] Consumer consumption drives major global environmental and social problems.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes bidirectional causality between individual consumers and societal systems. Economic uncertainty affects consumers, while consumer behavior contributes to global environmental problems. Both causal relationships are explicitly stated.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Economic uncertainty and global growth dynamics are societal-level conditions.; Individual: Consumers are specific people experiencing tough conditions.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Individual] Economic uncertainty holding back global growth causes tough conditions for consumers.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph ties societal-level economic uncertainty to consumers’ hardships, an explicit cross-scale causal effect. The 'consumption linked to problems' clause lacks a concrete actor and clear causality, so it was excluded.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph discusses consumer conditions and global problems but does not establish explicit causal links across different scales.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Individual | Individual -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'consumers' and their 'consumption', representing specific people or their collective actions.; Environmental and Societal: Encompasses 'economic uncertainty', 'growth', and 'the world’s biggest problems' like deforestation, climate change, etc., which are societal-level systems or conditions.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] Economic uncertainty held back growth, causing tough conditions for consumers, while consumption is linked to global environmental and societal problems.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes a two-way cross-scale interaction. 'Growth' (Environmental and Societal) being stifled led to 'tough conditions' for 'consumers' (Individual). Conversely, 'consumption' (Individual behavior) is identified as a cause of major 'environmental and societal problems'. Only two distinct scales (Individual and Environmental and Societal) were involved in explicit interactions, well within the limit.

Full Paragraph Text: However, each of our categories continues to innovate to meet the challenges posed by these trends and changing consumer preferences, such as products that are sustainably sourced. Whether it’s laundry products which use less water or compressed cans for deodorant packaging with 25% less aluminium, consumers are reacting positively to our innovations.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers who are reacting positively to innovations and have changing preferences for sustainably sourced products; Organizational: The company ('our categories') that innovates to meet consumer challenges and develops specific products like water-efficient laundry products and compressed deodorant cans
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumer preferences drive company innovation in sustainable products.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how consumer preferences and reactions causally influence organizational innovation decisions. Consumers' changing preferences for sustainable products explicitly prompt the company to develop specific innovations like water-efficient laundry products and compressed packaging.
gpt5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: ‘Trends and changing consumer preferences’ are societal-level norms influencing actions.; Organizational: ‘Our categories continue to innovate’ refers to a company/unit taking action.; Individual: ‘Consumers are reacting positively’ refers to individual people’s responses.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] Societal trends spur company innovation, which in turn elicits positive consumer reactions.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links societal trends to the organization’s decision to innovate, then links those innovations to consumer responses. These form a clear cross-scale chain, captured as two pairwise links.
o4_mini: Rationale: No explicit cross-scale causal links are present in the text.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: 'Consumers' are specific people reacting to products and thus represent the individual scale.; Organizational: 'Our categories' refers to product lines and 'our innovations' are outputs of a single company, mapping to the organizational scale.; Environmental and Societal: 'These trends' and 'changing consumer preferences' refer to broad market forces and collective shifts, fitting the environmental and societal scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] Societal trends and consumer preferences drive organizational innovation, which in turn positively influences individual consumers.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details a causal chain. First, 'these trends and changing consumer preferences' (Environmental and Societal scale) are identified as posing challenges that 'our categories' (Organizational scale) 'innovate to meet'. Second, 'our innovations' (Organizational scale) are stated to cause 'consumers' (Individual scale) to 'react positively'. All three distinct scales are involved with clear explicit links.

Full Paragraph Text: Acting alone Unilever can only do so much to make sustainable living commonplace. Acting in partnership with others it can help bring about transformational change at a societal level to tackle the world’s major social, environmental and economic issues. By adopting a leadership role, and working with governments, NGOs, suppliers and others, we are influencing change on a bigger scale, with a much bigger prize for the business on offer. We are deepening our efforts in three areas where we have scale, influence and resources to create transformational change: deforestation; sustainable agriculture and smallholder farmers; and water, sanitation and hygiene.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company taking leadership actions and working with partners; Environmental and Societal: Governments, NGOs, and societal-level transformational change being influenced
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever influences societal-level change by partnering with governments and NGOs.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) causally influencing transformational change at the societal level (Environmental and Societal) through leadership and partnerships. Only one clear cross-scale link is present.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company taking actions (adopting leadership, working with others).; Environmental and Societal: Text states change at a societal level on social, environmental, and economic issues.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever’s leadership and partnerships drive transformational change at the societal level.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states Unilever’s actions influence societal-level change. Mentions of partners indicate collaborators, but the clearest explicit cross-scale causal link is from the company to societal outcomes, so only two scales are used.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is acting as an organization to influence change.; Environmental and Societal: The changes being targeted are at a societal level, addressing major social, environmental, and economic issues.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's partnerships aim for societal-level change in sustainability.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as Unilever, as an organization, influences societal-level changes through partnerships. No other distinct scales were present in the text.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual:  'smallholder farmers' are specific groups of people.; Organizational:  'Unilever', 'NGOs', and 'suppliers' are specific organizations.; Environmental and Societal:  'societal level', 'governments', and 'world’s major social, environmental and economic issues' represent societal-level systems and challenges.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever (Organizational) influences both societal-level systems (Environmental and Societal) and individual groups like smallholder farmers (Individual).
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) initiating actions that lead to transformational change at a societal level (Environmental and Societal). It also states that Unilever's efforts directly aim to create change for smallholder farmers (Individual). These represent distinct cross-scale causal influences. No more than three distinct scales were identified with explicit causal links.

Full Paragraph Text: Delivering our business goals requires Unilever to recruit, develop and retain the right talent. We are determined to help all our people to be the best they can be, to help fulfil their potential and the potential of the business. Training and development are crucial at all levels and we strive to create a working environment that respects the human rights and interests of all our employees. Ensuring gender equality is a fundamental part of our approach while our Purpose of making sustainable living commonplace is a commitment that our people can engage with every day and make a reality through their work.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'all our people', 'employees', and individual talent that needs to be recruited, developed and retained; Organizational: Refers to Unilever as a company with business goals, training programs, working environment policies, and organizational Purpose
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Unilever's business goals drive talent development while employee potential fulfillment contributes to business success.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a bidirectional relationship where Unilever's organizational needs drive individual talent development, and individual employee fulfillment contributes back to organizational potential. Both causal directions are explicitly stated in the text.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Employees/’our people’ are specific persons affected and acting through their work.; Organizational: Unilever is a single company setting goals, approaches, and work environment.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Employees’ work makes Unilever’s purpose real, while Unilever’s goals require recruiting and developing employees.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links Unilever’s goals to actions affecting employees and states employees’ work realizes the company’s purpose. Only Individual and Organizational scales are present; no higher-scale actors are invoked.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company is focused on recruiting and developing talent.; Individual: Employees are the individuals whose potential is being developed and respected.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever's recruitment and development efforts impact employee potential and vice versa.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links demonstrate a clear causal relationship between Unilever's organizational actions and the individual development of employees. Both scales are essential to understanding the dynamics of talent management within the company.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Individual | Individual -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'our people', 'employees', 'talent' – specific individuals within or targeted by Unilever.; Organizational: Refers to 'Unilever', 'business', 'business goals', 'Purpose' – the company itself and its internal objectives/commitments.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'human rights', 'gender equality' (as societal norms Unilever strives to respect), and 'sustainable living commonplace' (as a broad societal goal/state).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's organizational support and purpose explicitly influence its individual employees, who in turn make societal-level goals a reality.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how Unilever's organizational actions, such as helping and providing a purpose, causally influence its individual employees. In turn, these individuals are explicitly stated to make the organizational purpose (a societal goal) a reality. Three distinct scales are clearly involved, showing a direct causal chain from Organizational through Individual to the Environmental and Societal level.

Full Paragraph Text: Personal Care is Unilever’s largest category. It includes five of Unilever’s 13 €1 billion brands: global names such as Dove, Rexona, Axe, Lux and Sunsilk.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph provides only descriptive information about Unilever's brand portfolio structure and categorization. No actors are described as taking actions that causally influence actors at different scales - it simply states facts about business categories and brand values without any cross-scale interactions.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph is descriptive (category size and included brands) and contains no explicit causal influence across different scales.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever's product categories and brands without indicating any causal interactions across different scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes relationships and attributes solely within the Organizational scale. 'Unilever' is an organization, 'Personal Care' is an internal category, and 'Dove, Rexona, Axe, Lux, Sunsilk' are brands belonging to Unilever. All mentioned entities operate at the same Organizational scale, and no explicit causal links across different hierarchical levels are provided.

Full Paragraph Text: Our Personal Care brands serve consumers across the full range of price points, playing to the category’s historic strengths of developing markets and reaching down while very deliberately adding a new dimension to the business through accessing faster growing premium segments.
claude4: Rationale: This paragraph describes a business strategy and market positioning but contains no explicit causal relationships between actors at different scales. It discusses serving consumers and accessing market segments, but these are descriptive statements about business activities rather than causal influences between specific actors.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: ‘Our Personal Care brands’ is a specific company/business unit.; Individual: ‘Consumers’ refers to people purchasing/using products.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The company’s personal care brands serve consumers across price tiers.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states the brands serve consumers, a direct organizational action affecting individuals. Mentions of the ‘category’s strengths’ imply sector context but do not clearly state a causal cross-scale effect, so only the most explicit two-scale link is included.
o4_mini: Rationale: The paragraph discusses market strategies without explicit causal links between different hierarchical scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: 'consumers' are specific people.; Organizational: 'Our Personal Care brands' refers to a portfolio of brands within a company, acting as a single organizational entity or formal internal units/teams. 'business' refers to the owning company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: 'category' refers to the entire personal care market sector, and 'premium segments' are parts of this market.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Personal Care brands serve consumers while strategically expanding into premium market segments to achieve business growth.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how Organizational entities (Personal Care brands) interact with Individual actors (consumers) by serving them, and how they also engage with the Inter-Organizational / Sector level (premium segments) by accessing them to expand their business. The mention of 'developing markets' describes an environmental context that brands leverage, but lacks explicit causal framing suitable for a cross-scale link.

Full Paragraph Text: We also continue to expand our presence by launching our brand portfolio in new geographic markets and by improving our presence in distribution channels where we are under-represented. Our current focus is the e-commerce channel and specialist drug stores.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes strategic expansion activities by a company but does not establish any explicit causal relationships between different scales. It only presents the company's plans and focus areas without showing how these actions influence or are influenced by actors at other scales.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A

Full Paragraph Text: Many of our leading brands have enjoyed success. Dove, our biggest brand, delivered another year of strong performance, driven by double-digit growth in deodorants and consistent performance in skin cleansing, which is rooted in a successful repeatable model of compelling communication and targeted innovation in bar and body wash. In hair, Dove’s success was helped by the strong start of the Advanced Hair Care range launched in the US and Europe. The brand is also building a premium offering with, for example, its new Oxygen Moisture hair care range in Europe and the launch of Dove Advanced Care solid deodorant sticks in the US.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes Dove brand performance and product launches but contains no explicit causal relationships between different hierarchical scales. All content focuses on organizational-level activities (brand performance, product development, market launches) without describing how these influence or are influenced by actors at individual, inter-organizational, or environmental/societal scales.
